titlepage.titleproper:
Finding Aid for
Arthur J. Tuttle Papers, 1849-1958
titlepage.author:
Finding aid prepared by:
Aprille Cooke McKay

did.abstract: U.S. District Court Judge, Eastern District of Michigan; Federal trial court case files, personal and professional correspondence, scrapbooks, University of Michigan student notebooks, and other materials concerning legal activities, Republican Party politics, prohibition, the election of 1924, Sigma Alpha Epsilon affairs; also family materials, including grandfather, John J. Tuttle, Leslie, Michigan, Ingham County official and businessman; and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The major portion of the collection was received in several accessions between 1945 and 1958 from Arthur Tuttle's daughters, Mrs. Thomas H. Bailey and Mrs. H. Blair Freeman (Donor No. 2104). Additional materials were received in three accessions in 1958, 1965, and 1985, from Mrs. Tuttle Bailey (Donor No. 3407).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Arthur J. Tuttle Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Arthur J. Tuttle was born on a farm in Leslie, Michigan, on November 8, 1868, to Ogden Valorius and Julia Elizabeth (McArthur) Tuttle. His grandfather, John J. Tuttle, settled in southern Michigan in 1837, establishing a farm. John Tuttle became a prominent citizen of Ingham County, serving as County Coroner, Justice of the Peace, School Director and Leslie Township Supervisor.

Arthur entered the University of Michigan and graduated with a Ph.B in 1892. He then enrolled in the university's law school and obtained a Bachelor of Laws Degree in 1895. Tuttle joined forty-four fraternal, civic, benevolent, law and scholastic organizations throughout his collegiate and professional life. Among them were: Phi Beta Kappa, Phi Alpha Delta, American and Detroit Bar Associations, Council of American Law Institute, Michigan State Horticultural Society, Detroit Boat Club, Detroit Athletic Club, Detroit Golf Club, Detroit Automotive Club and Rotary Club. For many years he served as bank president for the People's Bank of Leslie and director of the Home Telephone Company.

Tuttle's public life began with his election as Prosecuting Attorney of Ingham County in 1898. Here he gained notoriety for his dogged grand jury investigation of graft in connection with a military board that equipped troops during the Spanish-American War. Tuttle even had a subpoena served on governor Hazen S. Pingree while he was rushing for a train out of Lansing. Two brigadier generals were convicted, but received unconditional pardons from an angry Governor.

On March 11, 1903, Tuttle married Jessie Beatrice Stewart of Harsen's Island. The newlyweds honeymooned in Europe. Jessie gave birth to a daughter, Ruth, in March of 1904 and a second daughter, Esther, in September, 1905. In 1907, he joined the Lansing law firm of McArthur & Dunnebacke, becoming a senior partner. That same year he took a seat in the Michigan State Senate after being elected from the 14th district. He served in Michigan's Senate until 1910. In 1911 President William Howard Taft appointed him U.S. District Attorney for the Eastern District of Michigan. In 1912 he became the federal judge for the eastern district of Michigan.

As congratulatory letters were arriving, Jessie died unexpectedly on August 24th, only twelve days after he was sworn in. She was thirty-four. He never remarried, and raised his two daughters alone. Some of his happiest moments came when his daughters, Ruth and Esther, were admitted to the bar in 1930 after graduating from law school at the University of Michigan, and when they wed in a double ceremony in 1936.

Splitting his time between courtrooms in Detroit and Bay City, the Judge toiled diligently with the backlog of cases left by Judge Alexis Caswell Angell, winning respect for his hard work and dedication. It would be ten years before Congress would create another judgeship in the district to alleviate an ever-burgeoning workload. During that time Tuttle gained a reputation as a stern judge, especially in the sentencing of "white slavers" who through the prostitution trade had violated the federal Mann Act.

Prohibition unleashed a new wave of crime and in 1924 Tuttle sentenced Hamtramck Mayor Peter C. Jezewski, together with the city's former police commissioner and a former police lieutenant, to two years in Leavenworth for their role in a "beer ring". He was lenient on the saloonkeepers, however, saying, "conspiracy with the brain is more culpable than conspiracy with the hands."

When the overworked judge had time off, he would retreat to his family's 160-acre apple farm in Leslie. He was an avid hunter. Deer season often took him to northern Michigan, and his private judicial chambers were filled with trophy mounts.

In 1924, Tuttle and three others -- Republicans Hal H. Smith, Daniel W. Tussing, and Democrat Mortimer E. Cooley -- challenged U.S. Senator James Couzens in the September 9th primary. Tuttle was considered the strongest challenger. Tuttle had the backing of farmers and temperance groups and the endorsement of the Detroit Free Press while Couzens enjoyed the support of labor. Tuttle carried the out-state vote by a close margin, but lost in Detroit where Couzens defeated him by better than 2-1.

Back on the bench, Tuttle continued to work conscientiously. In his first twenty years of service, he was reversed only 35 times. He gained a reputation within the federal judiciary as an expert in patent and admiralty law. In 1927 he presided over hearings in the famous one-million-dollar libel suit brought against auto industrialist Henry Ford by Aaron Sapiro, a leader in the nation's farm cooperative movement. However, after a few months he recused himself upon being charged with bias by Ford's lawyers.

The two biggest and most controversial cases in Tuttle's 32 years on the federal bench came later in his tenure. On November 30, 1937, following the directive of a jury, Tuttle sentenced 38-year-old Polish immigrant Anthony Chebatoris to hang. A career criminal, Chebatoris shot an innocent bystander during a foiled bank robbery in Midland, Michigan. In 1846, Michigan had been the first English-speaking government in the world to abolish capital punishment for murder. State law, however, did not apply because the defendant had violated the National Bank Robbery Act of 1934.

The hanging of Chebatoris at the federal prison in Milan would be the only execution ever to take place within Michigan borders since statehood in 1837. Chebatoris was hanged in Milan at dawn on July 8, 1938. Governor Murphy called it "a blot on Michigan's civilized record."

In 1942, during another high-profile case, Judge Tuttle sentenced German-born Max Stephan, a Detroit restaurant owner, to hang for assisting a Nazi pilot who had escaped a Canadian prisoner-of-war camp. Lieutenant Hans Peter Krug contacted Stephan after crossing the Detroit River in a rowboat. Stephan gave him drinks, food, lodging and the services of a prostitute before paying his bus fare to Chicago. Krug, who was captured in San Antonio on his way to Mexico, testified against Stephan. Stephan was convicted by a jury on July 2, 1942.

The sentence surprised the packed courtroom of several hundred people. Few had expected a penalty of death. Stephan became the first person in the country convicted of treason since the Whiskey Rebellion of 1794. The U.S. Supreme Court refused to intervene three separate times. President Roosevelt., on July 1st, less than twelve hours before the traitor's date with death, commuted the death sentence to life imprisonment. The President stated that Stephan had been "properly convicted of treason," but that death was too harsh a punishment.

Arthur J. Tuttle had served the federal judiciary for 32 years when he took ill in late 1944. Tuttle died at Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit December 3rd at age 76. Judge Tuttle was buried at Woodlawn Cemetery in his native Leslie, Michigan. Hal H. Smith, described Judge Tuttle in an eloquent tribute on behalf of the Detroit Bar Association: "He had what I call a mental integrity, a conscience of the mind. The rule that governed him was his respect for the law as supreme arbiter. He had intense political and social convictions, but when the law and the statute did not square with them, he sternly repressed those convictions. He never let his judgments be swayed by them or his prejudice.

(The above sketch was adapted from "Arthur J. Tuttle: Dean of the Federal Bench" by Aaron J. Veselenak in The Court Legacy Newsletter, April, 1999, published by the Historical Society United States District Court of the Eastern District of Michigan. http://www.mied.uscourts.gov/_historical/newspdf/apr99.pdf)

scopecontent.p: The Arthur J. Tuttle Papers are arranged in 13 series: case files, opinions and jury instructions, topical office files, conciliation commissioners, criminal files, correspondence, letterbooks, scrapbooks, University of Michigan, financial matters, miscellaneous biographical materials, Tuttle family materials, and visual materials.

The Case files series (17 linear feet) dates from Tuttle's appointment to the Federal Bench in 1912 through his death in 1944 and consist of the files he kept in chambers about matters pending before him. These are not the court clerk's files, but are rather the judge's correspondence with attorneys, briefs, pleadings, opinions and other materials about the cases to which he required easy access. Some files contain transcripts of court hearings and have been so designated in the box listing. This series contains primarily civil cases, but there are also a few criminal cases. Files which substantially duplicated materials kept in the court clerk's files, or which related to routine matters such as uncomplicated bankruptcies were not retained, although all opinions written by Tuttle were retained and placed in the "Opinions and jury instructions" series. The files are arranged in chronological sequences according to the date the case was closed (not filed).

scopecontent.p: The Opinions and Jury Instructions series (2 linear feet) contains Tuttle's opinions and jury instructions for cases which are not represented in the case files series. They are arranged in chronological groupings, then alphabetically.

did.unittitle: Writs of Habeas Corpus and Certiorari 1917-1923

odd.p: includes case index and newspaper clipping

scopecontent.p: The Topical office files series (21.3 linear feet) includes files kept in Tuttle's chambers arranged by subject. They largely contain correspondence among court officials concerning the administration of the court. Tuttle's tenure saw an explosion in the extent of the Federal bureaucracy and this series documents the development of the bankruptcy court, the Prohibition Department of the Internal Revenue Service, Federal prison, probation and parole systems, immigration and naturalization procedures, the District Court Clerk's office, and the Justice Department and the Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts. The number of judges of the federal bench in Detroit was increased several times during his tenure and his "Additional Judge" files reflect his advocacy for new appointments. Tuttle's secretary usually pinned together incoming queries and copies of Tuttle's replies, allowing a clear record of intellectual interchange. The files relating to "New Federal Office Building" include floor plans and inventories of his chambers.

odd.p: (Relates details of investigation of break-in to agent's evidence cabinet and other courthouse thefts. Note that the IRS enforced liquor and narcotics laws during this period)
(Includes compiled statistics about caseloads, backlog, etc. and input from important Detroit businessmen, such as Henry Ford, who advocated for an additional judge)
(Tuttle marshals arguments to increase federal judge's salaries)
(Interesting political discussion of backing different candidates. Also a report from Tuttle to Denison about the American Law Institute's Congress to create the Restatement of Contracts.)
(Prior to the twenties, federal judges did not wear robes. This file contains judges' correspondence regarding the growing acceptance of robes, as well as a fabric sample)
(Senators Harry S. New and Knute Nelson)
(M.J. Kilsdonk, birth of naturalization bureaucracy in federal court)
(Blueprint of O'Meara's design for new Federal building)

Daugherty, Assistant U.S. Attorney General Mabel Walker Willebrandt, Congressman Louis C. Crampton, Detroit Police Commissioner James W. Inches, U.S. Prohibition Commissioner Roy Haynes. Includes newspaper clippings, printed matter, tips from the public, correspondence.)

did.unittitle: Cases delayed by litigation in other courts

odd.p: (Letter from Tuttle to the bankruptcy trustees regarding corruption among the bankruptcy attorneys)
(Judge Learned Hand, and many other Federal judges thanking Tuttle for sending them copies of his District Court Bankruptcy Rules)
(Son of a Tuttle's friend wants to be paid a higher than average fee for inventorying a bankruptcy estate.)

(Very interesting letter of complaint about the bankruptcy trustee's treatment of a female attorney. Tuttle's daughters were in college at this time and presumably planning their legal careers. Attorney Bessie McDonald apparently saw Tuttle as a supporter of women lawyers)

scopecontent.p: The Conciliation commissioners series (.7 linear feet) contains the records of an odd era in American Bankruptcy Law under the Frazier-Lemke Law whereby farmer debtors could appear before a county conciliation commissioner (usually a non-lawyer) and their creditors to try to force an agreement about the distribution of their assets. It was not very successful. These files contain the records of Tuttle's appointments of the various county commissioners and his correspondence with them.

odd.p: (Directors Mich. Bureau of Agricultural Industry A.C. Carton, Paul van Deinse, form letters)

did.unittitle: Conciliation Commission, Court Rules Various Districts

scopecontent.p: The Criminal files series (9 linear feet) contains correspondence related the imprisonment and parole of prisoners Tuttle sentenced. The judge wrote letters to the parole board containing fairly frank assessments of whether a given criminal was a "very bad man" or simply a young person who had fallen into bad company. Tuttle also worked to secure employment for prisoners he had sentenced, once they had been released from prison, if they asked for help. These files also contain social statistics Tuttle kept as to the defendants' nationality, age, family status, and previous offenses.

(mail theft, Tuttle writes letter for him to draft board to allow him to enlist)
(theft from railcar (coal), Wilson was pastor of black church)

(Beginning in 1938 the "Miscellaneous" files contain standardized dossiers on each case entitled Report of Probation Officer (Rudolph E. Boehringer or Charles T. Hosner,) containing a data sheet, and case narrative, including the offense, the penal institution, and the family and educational status of the prisoner; the judge's letter regarding probation is attached)

Vermont State Prison & House of Correction

odd.p: (includes individual folders for Fred L. Maurer (Mann Act) and Max Stephan (treason))

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series (22 linear feet) contain incoming correspondence of a more personal nature -- not related to his office as a federal judge. These include letters from political associates, family members, and friends and invitations to various social events.

did.unittitle: Letterbooks -- Outgoing correspondence, personal and professional

scopecontent.p: The Letterbooks series (19 linear feet) contains all Tuttle's outgoing correspondence, both personal and professional, in chronological order.
The Scrapbooks series (10 linear feet) contains scrapbooks filled with newspaper clippings concerning Tuttle, his family, and the cases he decided.

The University of Michigan series (3 linear feet) includes hard-covered notebooks from Tuttle's studies as an undergraduate and a law student. Also included are the Sigma Alpha Epsilon files which contain primarily incoming correspondence, 1915-1944, regarding the administration of the fraternity, including Tuttle's involvement in the government of the national organization.

scopecontent.p: The Financial matters series (1.2 linear feet) contains Tuttle's financial records, including tax returns.

scopecontent.p: The Miscellaneous biographical materials series (.5 linear feet) contains Tuttle's obituaries, bar memberships, and bills he proposed in the Michigan Legislature, among many other items.

scopecontent.p: The Tuttle family materials series (1.3 linear feet) includes two subseries: papers related to Arthur Tuttle's immediate family, his wife, Jessie Stewart Tuttle, daughters, Ruth and Esther Tuttle, and sister, Grace Tuttle Annis and papers related to John J. Tuttle, Arthur's grandfather. John J. Tuttle was school director and supervisor of Leslie Township, Ingham County, county coroner and justice of the peace, and agent for the Cayuga Chief Manufacturing Company, a maker of farm equipment, and an important figure in the founding of the Michigan Republican Party.

scopecontent.p: The Visual materials series (1 linear foot) includes photographs and albums. They contain images of Tuttle family members, friends, vacations, farms, and law offices.
